Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12209 O rientation and training.
(1)An agency shall ensure and document all the
following:
(a)That each social service worker and each social
service supervisor receives not less than 16 hours
of orientation after initial appointment and before
assumption of assigned duties.
1 of 10 personnel records reviewed, where the employee had been promoted to
supervisor, did not show documentation of 16 hours of orientation for this
employee.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
1 of 13 new employee records reviewed did not show proof of education for the
employee, identified as a case aide.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.

(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
3 of 13 new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of three
references:
• Two records documented two references for the respective employee.
• The third record documented one reference for the employee.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police, tribal police, or the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
2 of 13 new employee records reviewed showed the respective employee’s
ICHAT was completed four and seven days late with respect to each employee’s
10/23/2023 date of hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
6 of 13 new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a central
registry clearance from the department.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
2 of 23 employee records reviewed did not show compliance :
• One employee’s annual performance evaluation due by 1/31/2023 was
completed late on 2/21/2023.
• A second employee’s annual performance evaluation due by 8/4/2022 was
not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law.
An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
The agency did not complete new employee hire’s central registry clearances and
CPS History Checks via the Division of Child Welfare Licensing(DCWL) as
required. The 7 that were documented for the 13 new employees were from a
local Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) office. The agency
followed through and submitted central registry clearance requests to DCWL for
all its employee’s by 11/10/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
1 of 4 special evaluation records reviewed did not show documentation that a
copy of the special evaluation was provided to the foster parent.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of preparation for the child
and families for the child’s change of placement on 2/19/2023 and
5/5/2023.

• A second child’s record did not show documentation of preparation for the
child related to the child’s placement into a birth parent’s home.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
4 of 6 closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a) and
(b) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 4/5/2023; and the November 2021 Renewal inspection,
with a CAP approved on 12/9/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed where a 30-day report was due, did not
show documentation of the respective report which was due on 3/16/2023 and
7/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.

7 of 20 updated service plans (USP) reviewed (related to three of eight foster
child records reviewed) did not show documentation of a child specific behavior
support plan to be used by the caregiver with the child.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an adoptive
application is provided.
1 of 6 domestic adoption placement records reviewed did not show
documentation of an application for the adoptive family. The agency’s domestic
adoption supervisor reported since the adoptive parent was a foster parent, they
did not know to obtain an adoption application for this domestic adoption case.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be
provided to department; failure of licensee to
cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested,
the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall
be properly safeguarded by the child care organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:
1 of 4 special evaluation records reviewed indicated CPS (child protective
services) language and showed CPS’s involvement in the investigation.
Repeat Violation cited during the November 2021 Renewal inspection with a
CAP approved on 12/9/2021.

FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 5/13/2023-8/10/2023 USP.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 4/5/2023.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
3 of 8 open foster child records reviewed (related to 20 updated service plans
reviewed) did not show compliance:
• One child’s 5/13/2023-8/10/2023 USP treatment plan did not show
documentation of the birth parent’s signature.

• A second child’s 6/5/2023-6/28/2023 initial service plan (ISP) treatment
plan did not show documentation of the worker’s and supervisor’s
signature. This same child’s 5/5/2023-8/2/2023 USP treatment plan did
not show documentation of the birth father’s signature.
• A third child’s 8/5/2023-8/28/2023 ISP treatment plan was not signed by the
worker and supervisor until 10/9/2023; and the birth parent until 10/12/2023.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
C AP approved on 4/5/2023.
FOM 801-C Medical passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that the
caregiver was provided a copy of the child’s medical passport within two weeks of
the respective child’s 2/17/2023 and 6/5/2023 date of placement.
Repeat Violation cited during the January 2023 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 4/5/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12209(1)(a). Orientation and training.
• The agency was apprised that the tool it utilizes to document completion of
orientation must clearly show when the orientation topics were provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12603(1) Policy and procedures.
• The agency was provided consultation related to a new domestic adoption
policy related to families who wish to adopt after a new pregnancy/birth.
R400.12605(2) Adoptive family evaluation
• The agency was provided advisement related to non-face-to-face contacts
and documentation.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing period.
The incident related to a foster home complaint alleging the foster mother, along with
other actions, put hands on the foster child, yelled in the child’s face, made derogatory
remarks to the child, pushed the child into the basement, would not allow the child
upstairs or to use the bathroom without permission; and only gave the child two meals
daily, with the last meal being at 1:00pm. The investigation found the foster home in
violation of a number of foster home licensing rules, inclusive of the food and nutrition
rule, behavior management rule, applicant/licensee qualifications’ rule related to
character and suitability to meet the need of children and provide care, supervision
and protection; and the foster home applicant/licensee rule with respect to truthfully
assisting the agency with previous licenses and providing foster care. The agency
found the foster parent’s actions to be willful and revocation of the foster home’s
license was recommended.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards and time frames except statue
722.120(3) for which the agency received a violation, as indicated in this report.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to a foster home complaint alleging that the foster parent pushed
the foster child against a wall, hit the foster child with a sandal; and makes the foster
child do jumping jacks until told to stop or making the child stand with arms out while
holding heavy books until told to stop. During the investigation the foster parents self-
disclosed that she used physical corporal punishment on the foster children by
instructing them to do jumping jacks and hold heavy books for long periods of time.
A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parent that included a re-
review of the agency’s discipline and foster parent agreement policies; and the foster
parent utilizing trauma-responsive positive and consistent discipline techniques.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards related to this incident.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two corrective action plans during this reporting period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s Interim inspection where it
received the following rule and policy violations:
• R400.12312(4) Foster parent training.
• R400.12405(5)(a)-(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413(1) (c)(iii) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12413(1) (c)(f) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12417(1)(c)-(g) Foster parent information.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, And Time frames.
Supervisor Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment plan. Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
The agency provided proof of an in-service training on adoption quarterly progress
reports, and the requirements to provide timely submission of adoption evaluations
to families. The agency indicated this in-service would occur by 4/7/2023 and it
was held on 4/4/2023. The agency also provided samples of supervisor/worker
supervision conferences, staff meetings and calendars showing continued
discussions, reminders and focus with workers on change of placement
documentation requirements, family team meetings, medical and dental due
dates, and services connected with case closure; as well as in-service training
related to maintaining CPR and first aid certifications for foster parents, and foster
care supervisors’ approval of service plans. Notwithstanding the agency’s receipt
of repeat violations as cited in this renewal inspection report, the agency made
progress with this corrective action plan.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2023C0000543.
The complaint was received on 6/14/2023; and it alleged the foster parent was
not provided the child’s medical authorization, or any information about the child
prior to/at the time of placement. The special investigation found the agency in
violation of R400.12417(1) (h) and (j) for Foster parent information related to not
providing, the medical authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care; and other known information to enable the foster parent to provide a stable,
safe, and healthy environment for the foster child and the foster family. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on 10/4/2023.
It is noteworthy, the agency did not receive a citation related to this rule during this
renewal inspection; yet it is too early to assess the agency’s full compliance to this
corrective action plan.

Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a written chief administrator's report dated10/3/2023. The
report was completed as directed and no concerns were observed.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of their 2022 independent financial audit completed
9/30/2023. No concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to communication and discussion with the chief administrator, program
director, licensing supervisor, two foster care supervisors, the domestic adoption
supervisor, and the state ward adoption supervisor, I interviewed an adoption
specialist, and foster care specialist. No significant problems or concerns were
reported.
The agency does not provide independent living services, so no youth interviews
were required.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not reveal any safety or security issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had one safety alert on 10/17/2023. The safety alert related to an
unlicensed relative not having an operable smoke detector or carbon monoxide
detector in the home. Additionally, a household member, the grandfather not
allowing the DCWL Analyst access to his bedroom. The DCWL Analyst advised the
agency of their need to view the bedroom to ensure there were no safety concerns.
Resolution
The agency’s worker completed a home visit to the relative’s home and confirmed
the presence of and functionality of a combined smoke detector and carbon
monoxide detector on 10/19/2023. Additionally, they viewed the grandfather's room
and took pictures. A water damage issue on a bedroom’s ceiling in the family's home
had also been raised and that was addressed. The affected area was observed
carefully sanded and repainted. During a home visit on 10/30/2023, no signs of mold
were detected. To ensure the children's safety, the relative caregivers keep their
bedroom locked, preventing the children from gaining access. The relative
caregivers maintain the bedroom key on a lanyard, which the caregivers consistently
keep on their person. Photos of the grandfather’s bedroom and of the indicated
ceiling were provided.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
